Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: A large gathering has assembled for a special remembrance, and no one else present is authorized to lead.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, a message from Sara lighting up the screen: “Let’s finally have that dinner this week. Any evening works for me!” My heart leapt. We’d both been so busy, and I knew how much it meant to her that we spend time together, just the two of us, away from the noise of our routines. I started to type a reply, but then the mosque committee’s call came through. There was a special remembrance gathering tonight, and the usual imam was out of town. No one else was authorized to lead the prayers. They needed me.

I stared at the prayer schedule and then at Sara’s message. The mosque was already filling up, the community expecting guidance and presence. But Sara’s hope for a quiet evening together echoed in my mind. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on my chest—my duty to my faith and community, and my promise to be present for the woman I love. My fingers hovered over my phone, torn between two lives, each demanding all of me, and I didn’t know which to choose.
